title: Restore original white + beige/brown light theme and disable dark styling

requirements.summary: Restore the original light theme palette (white background with beige/brown accents) via theme tokens so all Tailwind/shadcn styling reflects it consistently.
acceptanceCriteria: The app background renders as white (or near-white) across all pages (trainer, client, admin) without any dark/black theme appearance.
Primary/accent UI elements (e.g., buttons, icons, gradient badges) use a beige/brown palette rather than blue/purple or dark-mode colors.
Theme tokens in `frontend/src/index.css` are updated so Tailwind/shadcn components consistently reflect the white + beige/brown palette (background, primary, secondary, muted, accent, border, ring).

file_operations.description: Update the light theme CSS variables to a white background with beige/brown (light brown) accents, ensuring key tokens (background/foreground/card/popover/primary/secondary/muted/accent/border/input/ring and any chart tokens used in gradients) align to the restored palette and propagate through Tailwind/shadcn token usage.

Align the root-level Tailwind theme variable definitions with the restored white + beige/brown palette to avoid inconsistent token sources during build/dev, keeping background near-white and primary/accent in beige/brown.

requirements.summary: Eliminate remaining dark-theme styling so the UI cannot visually switch to a dark/black palette (including under OS dark mode).
acceptanceCriteria: With OS-level dark mode enabled, the app still renders with the same white + beige/brown palette.
There are no pages/components that render with dark background/foreground tokens due to a `.dark` class being applied or dark variables being active.
No changes are required to any backend canisters or API behavior to achieve this.

file_operations.description: Neutralize dark-mode styling by removing or overriding the `.dark` variable block so it no longer defines a dark palette (set `.dark` variables to match `:root`), and ensure `color-scheme: light only` remains enforced for html/body so OS dark mode does not alter form controls or UA styling.
Remove or neutralize the `.dark` theme variable overrides in this global stylesheet as well, preventing any dark token activation if a `.dark` class appears anywhere in the DOM.

Harden light-only rendering by configuring the existing `next-themes` ThemeProvider usage to fully ignore system theme changes (keep `forcedTheme="light"` and disable system-driven switching), and add a small runtime guard that removes any accidental `dark` class from the root element on load.

Reinforce light-only behavior at the document level by ensuring the meta `color-scheme` remains `light only` and (if needed) adding a default light class/attribute to reduce any chance of dark UA styling when OS dark mode is enabled.
